duck: The steradian (symbol: sr) is the SI unit of solid angle.
The steradian (symbol: sr) is the SI unit of solid angle.

wiki.text:
The 'steradian' (symbol: 'sr') is the SI unit of solid angle. It is used to
quantify two-dimensional angular spans in three-dimensional space, analogously
to how the radian quantifies angles in a plane. The name is derived from the
Greek stereos for "solid" and the Latin radius for "ray, beam".

The steradian, like the radian, is dimensionless, essentially because a solid
angle is the ratio between the area subtended and the square of its distance
from the vertex: both the numerator and denominator of this ratio have dimension
length<sup>2</sup>. It is useful, however, to distinguish between dimensionless
quantities of different nature, so in practice the symbol "sr" is used to
indicate a solid angle. For example, radiant intensity can be measured in watts
per steradian (W·sr<sup>−1</sup>). The steradian was formerly an SI
supplementary unit, but this category was abolished from the SI in 1995 and the
steradian is now considered an SI derived unit.
wiki.title: steradian
